file_metadata.title: Disgust as a primary emotional system and its clinical relevance
file_metadata.abstract: <jats:p>This paper advocates for considering disgust as a primary emotional system within Panksepp’s Affective Neuroscience framework, which has the potential to improve the efficacy of psychotherapy with obsessive-compulsive disorder, hypochondriasis, and emetophobia. In 2007, Toronchuk and Ellis provided comprehensive evidence that DISGUST system, as they defined it, matched all Panksepp’s criteria for a primary emotional system. A debate ensued and was not unambiguously resolved. This paper is an attempt to resume this discussion and supplement it with the data that accumulated since then on DISGUST’s relationship with the immune system and the role of DISGUST dysregulation in psychopathology. We hope that renewed research interest in DISGUST has the potential to improve clinical efficacy with hard-to-treat conditions.</jats:p>

chunks.text: In a review of the literature on disgust, Knowles et al. (2018) noted a surge in scientific interest. This paper contributes to this trend by discussing disgust as a comprehensive emotional system closely linked to the immune system. This approach aims to help clinicians better identify and prioritize disgust dysregulation in various psychopathologies, potentially improving treatment efficacy for challenging conditions like post-traumatic OCD with contamination obsessions, emetophobia, and illness anxiety.
chunks.chunk_summary: Disgust is a complex emotional system linked to the immune system, and its dysregulation plays a significant role in various psychopathologies.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Post-traumatic OCD with contamination obsessions presents a complex treatment challenge due to the concurrent presence of PTSD and OCD symptoms.  Many OCD patients experience residual symptoms even after successful initial treatment, and a significant portion do not improve with any treatment (Bloch and Pittenger, 2010). Similarly, a substantial number of acute PTSD patients do not achieve stable improvement (Green, 2013). Addressing disgust dysregulation early in treatment is crucial for these conditions.
chunks.chunk_summary: Addressing disgust dysregulation is crucial in treating complex conditions like post-traumatic OCD, as many patients experience persistent symptoms despite treatment.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Disgust has often been misunderstood as mere oral distaste, hindering its recognition in clinical settings.  Distaste, nausea, retching, and vomiting are related but distinct concepts. Distaste is the oral rejection of bad-tasting food (Toronchuk and Ellis, 2007a). Nausea is the urge to vomit, while vomiting is the forceful expulsion of gastric contents, often preceded by retching (Zhong et al., 2021).
chunks.chunk_summary: Disgust is a distinct emotional system, different from related concepts like distaste, nausea, retching, and vomiting, which are often conflated.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Toronchuk and Ellis (2007a) defined the DISGUST system as an evolved response to internal threats from pathogens.  It enables anticipatory protection of the internal milieu through flexible actions before contact with noxious materials.  This contrasts with the FEAR system, which defends against external threats like predators (Panksepp, 1998). DISGUST is likely phylogenetically older than FEAR and is linked to the immune system.
chunks.chunk_summary: The DISGUST system is a flexible emotional system that provides anticipatory protection against internal threats from pathogens, distinct from the FEAR system.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: DISGUST is a flexible, long-lasting emotional system, distinct from the short-lived reflex of distaste.  It can be activated by multiple sensory pathways (olfactory, visual, tactile) and higher cognitive processes.  Examples include avoiding foul-smelling items, characteristic facial expressions (Ekman and Friesen, 1986), and tactile sensations like "slimy" (Miller, 1997).  It involves subneocortical processing, including the insula (Toronchuk and Ellis, 2007a).
chunks.chunk_summary: DISGUST is a complex emotional system activated by multiple sensory and cognitive pathways, involving subneocortical processing and a wider range of responses than distaste.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: While nausea, retching, and vomiting are functionally related to DISGUST (Zhong et al., 2021), they are not always synonymous (Fessler et al., 2005; Kaňková et al., 2022, 2023a, 2023b; Fejzo et al., 2023).  The urge to vomit is not necessary for all DISGUST processes.  Retching and vomiting are inflexible reactions to detected noxious material, while DISGUST enables anticipatory protection.  Distaste, nausea, retching, and vomiting are a subset of DISGUST-related processes.
chunks.chunk_summary: Nausea, retching, and vomiting are related to DISGUST but not essential components, as DISGUST involves anticipatory protection and broader responses.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The homeostatic settling point of the DISGUST system is a perceived safe internal milieu (Solms, 2018b). Negative DISGUST indicates a threat of infection, with intensity correlating with threat level. Positive valence arises during actions to minimize the threat, and contentment occurs when the settling point is reached.  Chronically unmet need for a safe internal milieu is a feature of OCD with contamination obsessions.
chunks.chunk_summary: The DISGUST system operates homeostatically, with negative affect signaling threat, positive affect during threat reduction, and contentment upon reaching a safe internal milieu.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: OCD with contamination obsessions involves dysregulated DISGUST and PANIC (Jackson and Solms, 2013; Panksepp and Biven, 2012). DISGUST dysregulation should be considered separately from FEAR or PANIC, as protecting the internal milieu is a distinct affect from fear of predators or separation distress.
chunks.chunk_summary: OCD with contamination obsessions involves dysregulated DISGUST, distinct from FEAR or PANIC, reflecting a unique need to protect the internal milieu.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: DISGUST likely evolved from a simple distaste reflex to a more flexible system involving learned retching and vomiting in response to pathogens, accompanied by nausea.  This system further developed into the context-dependent DISGUST system, working with the immune system to enable anticipatory and defensive strategies.  Humans can respond to pathogen threats through social cues like facial expressions or news reports.
chunks.chunk_summary: DISGUST evolved from a simple reflex to a complex, context-dependent system integrated with the immune system, enabling sophisticated anticipatory responses.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Toronchuk and Ellis (2007a) proposed DISGUST as a basic emotional system, fulfilling Panksepp's (2007) criteria: (1) triggered by unconditional stimuli; (2) generates coherent behavioral and physiological responses; (3) gates environmental inputs; (4) sustains activity after precipitating events; (5) triggered by cognitive activities; (6) regulates cognitive strategies.  They provided anatomical, functional, phylogenetic, and behavioral data supporting the first six criteria.
chunks.chunk_summary: DISGUST meets the criteria for a basic emotional system, based on anatomical, functional, phylogenetic, and behavioral evidence.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Toronchuk and Ellis (2007a) provided evidence that DISGUST: (a) relies on distinct neural circuitry; (b) organizes diverse behaviors beyond simple reflexes; (c) changes hedonic value in senses; (d) sustains hedonic changes beyond immediate exposure; (e) activates and regulates complex cognitive activities, including moral disgust.  They later addressed Panksepp's seventh criterion regarding psychiatric relevance (Toronchuk and Ellis, 2007b).
chunks.chunk_summary: Evidence supports DISGUST as a complex system influencing behavior, hedonic value, and cognitive activities, fulfilling criteria for a basic emotional system.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Panksepp's seventh criterion for a basic emotion, that it must generate psychiatrically relevant affective experience, is subjective and difficult to verify due to the lack of clear etiological explanations for most psychiatric conditions.  This paper aims to provide further support for DISGUST's relevance to psychopathology and clinical work.
chunks.chunk_summary: While Panksepp's seventh criterion for a basic emotion is debatable, this paper aims to further demonstrate the relevance of DISGUST in psychopathology.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This paper, along with Toronchuk and Ellis (2007a,b), aims to renew research interest in DISGUST as a primary emotional system.  Further empirical data are needed, including experimental studies in animals and humans, and investigation of DISGUST's neuroanatomy and dynamics.  This framework calls for adjustments in clinical models and practice, which have been negatively impacted by the limited view of disgust as mere distaste or nausea.
chunks.section: Some constraints in the research methodology of affective neuroscience
chunks.chunk_summary: Further research on DISGUST is needed to refine our understanding of its neuroanatomy, dynamics, and clinical relevance, moving beyond the limited view of disgust as distaste or nausea.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This paper will explore the evolutionary origins of protecting the internal milieu, the relationship between DISGUST and the immune system, the neuroanatomical substrates of DISGUST, relevant emotional concepts for clinical practice, and the diagnosis and treatment of clinical conditions where DISGUST plays a major role.
chunks.section: Some constraints in the research methodology of affective neuroscience
chunks.chunk_summary: The paper will cover the evolution, immune system connection, neuroanatomy, and clinical relevance of DISGUST.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Panksepp's research on neuroaffective systems used deep brain stimulation (DBS) in rats. However, rats are non-emetic, making it difficult to study disgust responses related to pathogens. This methodological limitation hindered disgust research in rodents.  Xie et al. (2022) developed a methodology to investigate retching-like behavior in non-emetic species using genetic labeling and chemogenetic inactivation of specific neurons, a more precise technique than DBS.
chunks.section: Some constraints in the research methodology of affective neuroscience
chunks.chunk_summary: Studying disgust in non-emetic rodents was limited by methodology until Xie et al. (2022) developed techniques to investigate retching-like behavior.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Understanding the origins of mind requires acknowledging that intelligence is collective, arising from individual cells.  During embryogenesis, a single cell develops into a complex organism, highlighting autopoiesis (self-construction) (Levin, 2019, 2022; Maturana and Varela, 1980; Varela et al., 1974).  A blastoderm can form multiple embryos, demonstrating that self-construction is an active process, not predetermined (Lutz, 1949).
chunks.section: The ancient process of defining and determining the internal milieu
chunks.chunk_summary: Intelligence is collective, originating from individual cells, and self-construction during embryogenesis is an active, not predetermined, process.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Each embryo must dynamically determine its boundaries and distinguish self from non-self (Fields and Levin, 2020, 2023; Friston, 2013; Friston et al., 2015, 2020).  This includes distinguishing between internal and external control signals, crucial for defending against biological hijacking (Fields and Levin, 2022; Levin, 2023).  Disgust may originate from recognizing transgressed boundaries by foreign agents.
chunks.section: The ancient process of defining and determining the internal milieu
chunks.chunk_summary: Embryos must dynamically define self/non-self boundaries, including distinguishing internal from external control signals, which may be the origin of disgust.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The immune system's role in self-organization highlights the challenge of distinguishing self from non-self (Geenen, 2021; Markose, 2022).  Pregnancy provides an example of altered self/non-self distinction, where the maternal immune system tolerates the fetus.  This tolerance may be linked to compensatory increases in disgust sensitivity.
chunks.section: The ancient process of defining and determining the internal milieu
chunks.chunk_summary: The immune system's self/non-self distinction is crucial, with pregnancy showcasing altered tolerance and potential compensatory disgust increases.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Disgust is a mammalian adaptation for protection against parasites and microbes (Curtis et al., 2004).  It serves as a mechanism for rejecting harmful substances (Rozin and Fallon, 1987).  Maintaining a clean nest environment is important for preventing disease spread through body excretions (Rozin and Fallon, 1987).  Disgust is elicited by spoiled food, infected animals, body excreta, poor hygiene, wounds, blood, and dead bodies (Haidt et al., 1994).
chunks.chunk_summary: Disgust evolved as a protective mechanism against pathogens, promoting rejection of harmful substances and maintenance of hygiene.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: As human society evolved, disgust extended to non-pathogen-related concepts, such as "unclean thoughts" or certain sexual preferences, termed "moral disgust" (Chapman and Anderson, 2013).  Disgust can also arise in unwanted sexual contact scenarios (Brake et al., 2021).
chunks.chunk_summary: Disgust has expanded beyond its original function to include moral and social domains, encompassing concepts like "unclean thoughts" and unwanted sexual contact.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The anterior insular cortex (aIC) is a key region in the DISGUST network, though not solely responsible for its function (Toronchuk and Ellis, 2007a,b).  Functional imaging and intracerebral event-related potentials studies support aIC's involvement in disgust processing (Jabbi et al., 2008; Pujol et al., 2018; Gan et al., 2022). Lesions to aIC disrupt disgust experience and recognition.
chunks.chunk_summary: The anterior insular cortex (aIC) is crucial for disgust processing, as evidenced by functional imaging studies and lesion studies.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Conditioned taste aversion (CTA) is an associative learning paradigm used to study disgust-related processes. CTA in rodents depends on the aIC and amygdala, particularly the basolateral amygdala (BLA) (Toronchuk and Ellis, 2007a; Tuerke et al., 2012; Kayyal et al., 2019; Lavi et al., 2018; Inui et al., 2019).  The aIC-BLA network encodes flexible memories related to CTA.
chunks.chunk_summary: The aIC and basolateral amygdala (BLA) are key for conditioned taste aversion (CTA), forming a flexible memory system for disgust-related learning.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The basal ganglia's (BG) role in DISGUST is less clear, with mixed results in research (Sprengelmeyer et al., 1996, 1997, 2003; Chapman and Anderson, 2012).  Left hemisphere lesions in the basal ganglia appear to disrupt DISGUST (Calder et al., 2000; Straube et al., 2010; Holtmann et al., 2020).  More research is needed to clarify BG's involvement.
chunks.chunk_summary: The role of the basal ganglia in disgust is uncertain, with some evidence suggesting left hemisphere involvement but requiring further investigation.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The nucleus tractus solitarius (NTS) in the medulla is involved in reflexive vomiting (Toronchuk and Ellis, 2007a,b).  The dorsal vagal complex (DVC), including the area postrema (AP), NTS, and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus (DMV), mediates vomiting (Zhong et al., 2021).  AP and NTS lack the blood-brain barrier, allowing rapid response to stimuli in blood and cerebrospinal fluid.
chunks.chunk_summary: The dorsal vagal complex, including NTS, AP, and DMV, mediates vomiting, with AP and NTS lacking the blood-brain barrier for rapid response.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Xie et al. (2022) confirmed the involvement of NTS, AP, and DMV in retching-like behavior in mice using genetic labeling and chemogenic deactivation.  Taste and interoception pathways involving aIC, amygdala, and NTS differ between rodents and primates.  Primates have direct connections from NTS to the thalamus, bypassing the pons (Craig, 2002), allowing a direct cortical image of the body's physiological condition.
chunks.chunk_summary: Rodent and primate disgust pathways differ, with primates having a direct NTS-thalamus connection for cortical representation of bodily state.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Pathway differences between rodents and primates exist in other neuroaffective systems as well.  For example, sensory inputs converge on the tail of the striatum in rodents but not primates (Lee et al., 2023).  Primates have inhibitory neurons in the reuniens nucleus of the thalamus with connections to the amygdala, unlike rodents (Joyce et al., 2021).  Structural differences in the amygdala also exist (Morgan and Amaral, 2013).  Caution is needed when applying rodent research to primates.
chunks.chunk_summary: Rodent and primate brains differ in various neuroaffective pathways, including striatal inputs, thalamic connections, and amygdala structure, requiring caution in cross-species comparisons.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Humans may have unique lateralized re-representations of bodily state in the right anterior insula, potentially linked to bodily self-awareness (Craig, 2002).  DISGUST is a hierarchical system with innate distaste at the brainstem level, more flexible CTA memories involving aIC and BLA, and context-dependent neocortical memories like moral disgust.  Top-down and bottom-up influences exist between these layers (Panksepp and Biven, 2012).
chunks.chunk_summary: DISGUST is hierarchically organized, from brainstem-level distaste to complex cortical memories, with dynamic interactions between levels.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Insula activity occurs in other emotional contexts besides DISGUST, and many brain regions are multifunctional (Solms and Turnbull, 2018).  A more nuanced model of taste and interoceptive processing is needed (Evrard, 2019).
chunks.chunk_summary: Brain regions, including the insula, are multifunctional, and a more detailed understanding of sensory processing is needed.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Koren et al. (2021) showed that the insula cortex (InsCtx) stores and retrieves immune-related information in mice.  Colitis and peritonitis activated distinct InsCtx neuronal ensembles, and reactivating these ensembles heightened immune activity.  The Compensatory Prophylaxis Hypothesis (CPH) proposes that increased disgust augments internal milieu protection when the immune system is suppressed (Schaller and Duncan, 2007; Fessler and Navarrete, 2003).
chunks.chunk_summary: The insula cortex stores and retrieves immune information, and the Compensatory Prophylaxis Hypothesis (CPH) suggests disgust compensates for immunosuppression.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The CPH, initially related to progesterone's immunosuppressive effects during the menstrual cycle (Fessler and Navarrete, 2003; Miyaura and Iwata, 2002), suggests increased disgust sensitivity in the luteal phase.  While some studies support this (Fleischman and Fessler, 2011; Milkowska et al., 2019; Olatunji et al., 2020; Miłkowska et al., 2021; Želaźniewicz et al., 2016), others find no correlation (Fessler and Navarrete, 2003; Stern and Shiramizu, 2022; Jones et al., 2018; Timmers et al., 2018).
chunks.chunk_summary: The CPH proposes increased disgust sensitivity during the luteal phase due to progesterone's immunosuppressive effects, but findings are mixed.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Disgust may be upregulated in other immunomodulation contexts. Increased disgust sensitivity is observed in recently sick individuals (Stevenson et al., 2009), those perceiving vulnerability to disease (Sarolidou et al., 2020), women with luteal phase infections (Milkowska et al., 2019), and those with first-trimester health problems (Dlouhá et al., 2023).
chunks.chunk_summary: Disgust sensitivity increases in various contexts of immunomodulation, including sickness, perceived vulnerability, and pregnancy-related health issues.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Elevated disgust sensitivity in the first trimester of pregnancy, a period of increased vulnerability to pathogens, supports the CPH (Fessler et al., 2005; Żelaźniewicz and Pawłowski, 2015).  Kaňková et al. (2022) linked elevated first-trimester disgust to decreased cytokine levels, suggesting compensatory disgust for insufficient immune adaptation.  They also found negative correlations between disgust and hCG levels, a hormone contributing to immune tolerance (Kaňková et al., 2023a; Schumacher et al., 2013).
chunks.chunk_summary: Elevated disgust in early pregnancy may compensate for reduced immune function, as evidenced by correlations with cytokine and hCG levels.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Kaňková et al. (2023b) found a weaker disgust response to infection risk in pregnant women, possibly due to pre-existing elevated disgust from pregnancy.  The CPH explains increased disgust in individuals needing greater protection from infectious diseases, particularly during vulnerable reproductive periods.
chunks.chunk_summary: Pregnant women, already experiencing elevated disgust, show weaker disgust responses to additional infection risks, supporting the CPH.
chunks.authors: ["Alexey Tochilov", "George F. R. Ellis", "Sarka Pankova", "Jeffrey S. Burgdorf", "Michael Levin"]
